header.title: Students Pranked During Teacher's Lesson on Ageism | Field Tripped
header.subtitle: NA
header.postText: Does age or the appearance of youth affect how we view others? To answer this question, Mr. Ferroni turns to his students to for a little experiment on ageism.. . Special thanks to the students at USH who filmed and produced this video.. . We love to connect with YOU, no matter what language you speak. commentThread.commentText: There is no doubt that teacher are targeted with PAR by administration because of their age. Where I live, we can't even get ahold of the PAR data, but we know PAR is ageist. You can see the data if you click here and scroll down: [LINK]
5:58 well luckily you still look young. Also the old teacher was boring.
I'd choose Paul.

I really think any time you have students apply lessons to something that's familiar to them (movie characters, in this instance), they're going to be more engaged. I wish they would've switched lesson plans for a different group of kids--wonder what the outcome would've been then.
Dang everybody on YouTube is talking about sociopaths and psychopaths
Moral of the story: "Supposed youth ageism and discrimination is solved with.... skin moisturizer!"
I too would've chosen Mr. B, and not because he's younger, but because it would probably take a significantly less effort to get an A without having to do actual work

We got 3 explinations of...how many???? There was an entire classrom. Let them all tell us why they chose what they did. Unless you're adjenda driven. 
Which it seems like u are.
You havent even figured out that the algorithm on YouTube depends a lot on watch time. So a longer video is only going to benefit you. 
Missed opportunity here. Thats the problem with channels like these. Im over it. Unsub. The individual creators are leaps and bounds ahead of you guys in the youtube game.

I'm 70 and I can tell you ageism IS a thing. Once you hit like 40, you are OLD. I remember I was out shopping when I was 40. I was looking at kids clothes...my daughter was 4 and my son was 7, but they weren't with me. A lady shopper near me looked over and said "Are you a grandmother?" I was totally flabbergasted! How in the world could she think that? It then occurred to me that, in fact, I could be a grandmother at 40. What a wake up call. I was carded for real until i was 35, so this just threw me for a loop. At my curren t age, younger people always seem to assume I'm senile and set in my ways. Come on! I have kept myself in shape and I keep up with current clothing trends (although I do go for looks that would suit a 30 ye ar old and not a teen). I'm on Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest and Instagram. I have been playing Pokemon GO since it came out, and I used to be in Second Life. In other words, I think young. My Great Aunt used to wear orthopedic shoes and house dresses...typi cal old lady clothes...I swore I would never look like that, and I don't. I think I relate to younger people. I have a 5 year old Granddaughter, and I hope when I die, she won't remember me as this old lady...in fact, I hope she will say "WOW, she was too young to die". I'm afraid ageism isn't going away, but maybe if people will start giving someone a chance before making assumptions, that would be a start.
Yo do those google classroom codes actually work?
Yep, this was a bad experiment. It def did not prove agism, it much more likely to have proven that these students preferred the easy teacher.

Pretty much the reason they chose Mr.B was because he would give them less work and it'd be more fun (who doesn't want to talk about psychotic TV show characters?) They would probably choose Mr. Paul if it were reversed

I also think that students tend to like substitutes that they see as "easy." When my students tell me they loved the substitute they had I always ask them why. Their response is pretty much the same every time: "he/she let us do _____." Of course, I don't know the students' motivations in this class, but just an observation from my own experience. I also agree with the top commenter, that if it were a real experiment, the teachers would have had the same lesson. Then you really test if age played a factor.

replies.commentText: Exactly!!!!!

commentThread.commentText: It's not ageism. It's because students are not in school to learn, they're there to socialize, they're stupid. So in turn they want to stupid person 'teaching' them so they don't have to do work.
you forgot the biggest factor that influences this situation: laziness
This is such a badly designed experiment

I would have chosen Mr. B, not because he's younger, but because he made the assignment interactive. Although Mr. Paul's lesson plan was far more interesting, the average high school student would prefer a lesson plan where they get to interact with other students as oppose to sitting there and listen to the teacher talk.

Ageism is a real thing, this has already been studied 🤔 Love the concept of exploring it within a class context, but do it with accurate questions in mind! It's equally important to teach viewers about setting up an scientifically plausible premise 👍
'Megan from Drake and Josh' I CACKLED
I would be curious to see this repeated at a college/university level where students are actually paying for their education.

This experiment doesn't work correctly. Because the younger teacher approached the students with something they could relate with, tv shows, and asked them to interact. Where the older teacher told them to read definitions and watch videos. I find that teachers (no matter their age) who interact with their students, will always get a much better student response.
I hate unprofessionalism so I'd actually dislike this Mr B a lot.
Meghan from drake and Josh. Accurate.
LOL
is that DSP?
how is this a prank
I'm in college myself so I understand why they picked Mr. B. Not because of his age, but because he was the "easier" sub. That said, Mr. Paul's plan sounded significantly more interesting to me.

replies.commentText: Exactly

commentThread.commentText: HORRIBLE experiment. If 'age' is the independent variable everything else needs to be the same. Youre assuming that students are picking based on the best lesson when they actually have other motivatations. Dumb, boring experiment.

replies.commentText: Age and that which goes with it, is the independent variable. The lesson plan was designed to showcase the individual, their age and their strong suits, which is exactly the point of the experiment. But they were both discussing/teaching/talking about sociopaths and psychopaths, which is as close as you possibly can get. You can't have a social experiment where one person is the same as the other based on age, ability and what goes with that, when people are drastically different ages. This experiment cannot be done in a math class where they could have taught the same material, with the same lesson plan, etc, for a result because this is not a math class... he is not a math teacher. Therefore it will not be taught the same way because it will not be a straight forward, this and this will give you this result, instruction of the material.
But they're assuming that the students motivation is picking the best teacher. They all KNEW that the older guy was the better teacher but maybe they wanted the guy who was less strict for example.

commentThread.commentText: that girl at the end is very smart...
This is interesting to watch while being a young teacher myself. Haha.
This has nothing to do with age tho..

Had nothing to do with ageism in my opinion. It was more about who the students thought was going to be an easy A and who they could get away with stuff. With the older more experienced gentleman, they knew it was going to be a real class with real work. This generation tends to be more lazier than past. I think the experiment question would have been better phrased as, "Who would be the better teacher". That would have been a true test.

replies.commentText: True
That was exactly what he said at the beginning and what he said to the students. That is how he put the question to them and what he was saying. Bullshit on the lazy part.

commentThread.commentText: This is depressing.  "...because apparently youth matters more than knowledge."

replies.commentText: Nah.  This is totally sensationalized. Read my comment below.

Of course it's an easy A....and to a degree ageism is a part of it, however the bigger part of it is the top heavy administration issues we're having (in higher ed particular...as a professor for over 18 years, the issue is within admin). The issue is with how they utilize adjuncts within the classroom (which is what I've been, as full time jobs are hard to get). Why pay full time wages when you can get people to work for 2k/semester. Until that's fixed, we won't see changes.

I see where you're coming from, as I too have taught for 20 years... but as far as this video, my opinion still stands. It's not about ageism. This is about lazy students and who they think is going to be an easier teacher. Nothing more , nothing less.
@ANTONNE BROUSSARD you are the worst kind of teacher.
@# feliciasbeard ok

commentThread.commentText: Megan from Drake and Josh

I remember how I used to think in highschool. I would have picked the younger teacher not because of his age, but in order to get high marks with much less effort and be able to be laid back in classes and learn less. I don't think age is a key element in this experiment! Try again with making older teacher give them easy tasks in stead!

replies.commentText: Exactly. That's all that was about. Not because "they could relate" get out of here!

That's the point, based on experience and the ageism, their structure of teaching the material will inherently be different because they have developed the tools and ideas to teach more effectively. This comment is the basis, and the proof, of an ageism experiment with this exact same result.

@# feliciasbeard My favourite elementary school teacher was a very kind guy, near his retirement. He let us do whatever we wanted in his classes, you could pick to learn only one lesson and you'd get an A for the rest of the year. And while I did my best to listen to his lectures which he held very quietly, almost none of the other kids did, and some would even leave the classroom or stand up on desks and things like that. But everybody loved that teacher! I later went on and actually graduated biology, but lacking elementary knowledge sometimes haunted me throughout my studies. He lives nearby me, so we sometimes meet - we greet everytime, he asks about my grandma's health which is very lovely. He was the best teacher AND the oldest. Thanks for reading my memoirs. 😊
Good point Scattered, never thought of that!
